text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section if you see a recipe that calls
for lemongrass do you just kind of turn
the page and make another recipe well
you don't have to because I'm going to
show you how to deal with lemongrass
lemongrass is becoming increasingly
available these days I can even get it
in my local supermarket so you want to
trim off this dry end over here and then
the skinny part of the stem then just
peel it just like you would a scallion
make a little slit if you have to and
you want to take off the really tough
outer layers now if you're going to use
lemongrass for something like a curry
paste where you're going to put it in a
food processor or really pound it with a
mortar and pestle you can at this point
just chop it up and then go ahead and
use it for the recipe but if you're
going to chop up the lemongrass to use
for say a stir-fry or if you wanted to
cut it into pieces and put it in a soup
you have to bruise it first because all
of the good essential oils are within
that tough skin so if you bruise it the
oils will come to the surface more
readily so to bruise it you could use a
heavy rolling pin or if you have one of
these meat tenderizers this is great to
just smash it if you're going to make a
soup just take this whole thing and
throw it right in the soup pot if you're
going to make a stir fry you can just at
this point just mince this up you see
that's how to deal with lemongrass it's
not so hard so next time don't turn the
page
